awd_titl_txt: Community Facility Support for Geochronology and Thermochronology at the Arizona LaserChron Center
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent developments in geochronologic methods and instrumentation are revolutionizing many different aspects of Earth Science research. Some of the most exciting advances are being driven by Laser-Ablation ICP Mass Spectrometry (LA-ICPMS), which generates U-Th-Pb ages and complementary geochemical information rapidly, with micron-scale spatial resolution, and with the precision necessary to address a wide range of problems in Earth Science.  The Arizona LaserChron Center (ALC) is a community facility that utilizes LA-ICPMS to determine U-Th-Pb ages, Hf isotope ratios, and trace element abundances from a variety of minerals that occur in sedimentary, igneous, and metamorphic rocks. We also utilize a dedicated Scanning Electron Microscope that generates the high-resolution and high-magnification images necessary for state-of-the-art micro-analysis. Primary goals of the ALC are to (1) generate U-Th-Pb ages, Hf isotope ratios, and trace element concentrations of the best precision, accuracy, and spatial resolution possible from LA-ICPMS, (2) provide opportunities for researchers from around the world (and especially NSF-supported scientists) to use our instruments and expertise to address geologic problems, (3) drive the development of new techniques and applications of geochronology, thermochronology, and petrochronology, (4) build new cyberinfrastructure for data acquisition, analysis, and archiving, and (5) use every aspect of facility operation as an opportunity to enhance expertise and diversity among geochronologists and users of geochronology. Research at the ALC is conducted in a highly collaborative mode, with ALC scientists providing assistance with all aspects of a project (from initial design of the study to final publication of results) and faculty members and students from other institutions visiting the lab to generate their own data and learn the theory and methodology of U-Th-Pb geochronology.

Funding from this award will enable the ALC to facilitate the acquisition of geochronologic information in support of a large number of NSF-funded projects. These projects focus on generating new knowledge about the growth of continents, emergence of life, processes of mountain building, mechanisms and timing of volcanic eruptions, distribution of sediment through space and time, formation of mineral, energy, and water resources, and linkages between climate and tectonics. The ALC will also continue to help drive the development of numerous new analytical techniques, applications, and instruments, as well as the cyberinfrastructure needed to utilize and integrate the information generated. Educational activities will include hosting visits from several hundred faculty and student researchers per year, teaching short courses at annual meetings, developing materials that can be used in Earth Science courses, providing opportunities for non-scientists to learn about geochronology, creating new tools for displaying and interpreting geochronologic data, and driving the development of global databases that host U-Th-Pb geochronologic information.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Outcome #1 has been to generate geochronologic information that is used to address a wide range of critical problems in Earth Science. Research conducted at the ALC has been fundamental to our understanding of processes such as the generation of and reworking of continental crust; movement of plates and assembly of supercontinents; petrogenesis of Large Igneous Processes and magmatic flare-ups in batholiths; development of thick crust and high elevation plateaus; formation of Proterozoic, Paleozoic, and Quaternary ice sheets; formation of ore deposits and accumulation of hydrocarbons in many regions of the world; evolution of the Arctic and Mediterranean ocean basins; and connections between paleoclimate, paleogeography, and tectonics. We have also explored applications of geochronology to other fields, such as the timing of early dinosaur evolution, archaeological sourcing of artifacts, developing methods to determine the provenance of gemstones, and chronology of meteorites and Mars.

Outcome #2 has been to develop and report new analytical methods and software tools that take advantage of the spatial resolution and efficiency of LA-ICPMS. The ALC has been very active in improving the precision, accuracy, efficiency, and spatial resolution of U-Th-Pb analyses of zircon and other minerals, with techniquedevelopment papers published nearly every year between 2006 and 2023. These improvements resulted from our in-house research, collaborations with academic researchers at other institutions, interactions with engineers at companies that manufacture mass spectrometers and laser ablation systems, and work with faculty members and students in Computer Science at the University of Arizona.

Outcome #3 has been to provide geochronologic training and educational opportunities for a large number of researchers and students. Each year the number of collaborators has increased with 371 people during Year 1, 386 people during Year 2, and 422 people during Year 3. This has been accomplished mainly through in-person visits now that Covid-related travel restrictions have eased. It is clear, however, that many esearchers prefer to continue collaborating with us remotely, and we assume that this will be the case in the future. Fortunately, as described in a Covid video on the ALC YouTube Channel, we are now able to use Zoom, TeamViewer, and Chromium to effectively conduct remote sessions with individual researchers and groups of Workshop participants.

We also have developed extensive web-based resources that are of significant benefit to the broader Earth Science community. These resources include detailed descriptions of our analytical methods (hosted on our lab web page), videos that provide visitors with assistance prior to, during, and following their visits (hosted on the LaserChron YouTube channel), software to make plots and analyze data (available open-access from GitHub), and short courses on geochronologic methods and applications that can be used for individual instruction or in a classroom setting (available from our web page). A two-day short course on U-Pb Geochronology and Thermochronology was taught in association with the 2021, 2022, and 2023 Annual Meeting of the Geological Society of America. Software developed at the ALC is also an effective educational tool given that it provides background information on every step of data reduction and analysis.

Outcome #4 has been the enhancement of human resources in the Earth Sciences, with an emphasis on increasing both technical expertise and diversity. We have accomplished this in part by operating the ALC mainly with a diverse group of students and post-docs, rather than permanent research scientists, such that our technical expertise and commitment to building diversity are continually transferred to other institutions. We also encourage our faculty collaborators to bring students to the lab and, during the Covid pandemic, to participate in virtual sessions and workshops. Travel, subsistence, and analytical costs for student researchers are subsidized using NSF Participant Support funds, and this has been very effective in increasing the number of undergraduate and graduate students involved in research. During the award period we developed and implemented a "Plus One" Program, where we cover all costs of involving eight undergraduate students from under-represented minorities in a research project. These efforts have been highly successful -- during Year 3, we supported the research activities of 208 students and 98 members of under-represented minority groups.
